disease: Common Cold  Runny Nose  Sneezing  Cough
cure: Rest, stay hydrated, take vitamin C, use steam inhalation, and consider over-the-counter decongestants.
Drink plenty of fluids, rest, take antiviral medications if prescribed, and use fever reducers like acetaminophen.

disease: Migraine  Headache  Sensitivity to Light  Nausea
cure: Rest in a dark room, use a cold compress, stay hydrated, and take prescribed migraine medications.

disease: Sinusitis  Stuffy Nose  Facial Pain  Pressure in Head
cure: Use saline nasal spray, stay hydrated, inhale steam, and take antihistamines or decongestants.

disease: Strep Throat  Sore Throat  Fever  Swollen Lymph Nodes
cure: Take prescribed antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin), drink warm fluids, and use throat lozenges.

disease: Asthma  Shortness of Breath  Wheezing  Chest Tightness
cure: Use prescribed inhalers (bronchodilators), avoid allergens, and take corticosteroids if needed.

disease: Bronchitis  Persistent Cough  Chest Congestion  Mucus
cure: Drink warm fluids, use a humidifier, avoid smoking, and take cough suppressants or bronchodilators.

disease: Pneumonia  Fever  Chills  Shortness of Breath  Chest Pain
cure: Take prescribed antibiotics (if bacterial), get rest, stay hydrated, and use oxygen therapy if severe.

disease: Tuberculosis  Chronic Cough  Night Sweats  Weight Loss
cure: Take a full course of prescribed antibiotics (isoniazid, rifampin), maintain good nutrition, and avoid spreading infection.

disease: Ear Infection  Ear Pain  Fluid Drainage  Hearing Loss
cure: Take antibiotics if bacterial, use warm compresses, and take pain relievers like ibuprofen.
Use antibiotic or antihistamine eye drops, maintain eye hygiene, and avoid touching the eyes.

disease: COVID-19  Fever  Cough  Loss of Smell  Shortness of Breath
cure: Rest, stay hydrated, monitor oxygen levels, take antiviral medications (if prescribed), and isolate.
Take antihistamines for itching, keep skin cool, use calamine lotion, and get plenty of rest.
Rest, drink fluids, take vitamin A supplements, and use fever reducers if necessary.

disease: Mumps  Swollen Glands  Fever  Muscle Pain
cure: Rest, apply warm compresses, drink fluids, and take pain relievers like acetaminophen.

disease: Dengue Fever  High Fever  Joint Pain  Rash
cure: Rest, stay hydrated, take paracetamol for fever, and avoid NSAIDs like ibuprofen.

disease: Typhoid Fever  High Fever  Abdominal Pain  Weakness
cure: Take prescribed antibiotics (ciprofloxacin or azithromycin), drink oral rehydration solutions, and eat easily digestible food.
Take prescribed antimalarial drugs (artemether-lumefantrine, chloroquine) and avoid mosquito bites.

disease: Food Poisoning  Vomiting  Diarrhea  Stomach Cramps
cure: Stay hydrated, drink oral rehydration solution, rest, and eat bland foods.

disease: Gastroenteritis  Nausea  Vomiting  Diarrhea  Stomach Pain
cure: Drink electrolyte-rich fluids, eat small frequent meals, and take probiotics.
Take prescribed proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole), avoid spicy foods, and reduce stress.

disease: Appendicitis  Severe Abdominal Pain  Nausea  Fever
cure: Immediate medical attention required; surgery (appendectomy) is the standard treatment.

disease: Hepatitis B  Jaundice  Fatigue  Dark Urine
cure: Take antiviral medications if needed, avoid alcohol, and maintain a healthy diet.

disease: Diabetes  Frequent Urination  Excessive Thirst  Fatigue
cure: Maintain a healthy diet, monitor blood sugar levels, exercise, and take prescribed insulin or medications.

disease: Hypertension  High Blood Pressure  Headaches  Dizziness
cure: Reduce salt intake, exercise regularly, manage stress, and take prescribed antihypertensive drugs.

disease: Heart Disease  Chest Pain  Shortness of Breath  Fatigue
cure: Adopt a heart-healthy diet, exercise, avoid smoking, and take prescribed medications like beta-blockers.

disease: Stroke  Sudden Weakness  Slurred Speech  Numbness
cure: Immediate emergency treatment required; physical therapy and medications for prevention.
Take anti-inflammatory medications, do gentle exercises, and apply hot/cold therapy.
Take calcium and vitamin D supplements, do weight-bearing exercises, and take prescribed medications if needed.

disease: Anemia  Fatigue  Pale Skin  Shortness of Breath
cure: Increase iron intake (green leafy vegetables, red meat), take iron supplements, and treat underlying causes.

disease: Epilepsy  Seizures  Confusion  Loss of Consciousness
cure: Take prescribed anticonvulsant drugs, avoid triggers, and ensure a safe environment during seizures.

disease: Parkinson’s Disease  Tremors  Slow Movement  Stiffness
cure: Take prescribed dopamine-enhancing medications, do physical therapy, and engage in regular exercise.

disease: Alzheimer’s Disease  Memory Loss  Confusion  Behavioral Changes
cure: Take prescribed medications (donepezil, memantine), maintain a routine, and ensure a supportive environment.

disease: Depression  Persistent Sadness  Fatigue  Sleep Issues
cure: Seek therapy, engage in physical activity, practice mindfulness, and take prescribed antidepressants if needed.

disease: Anxiety  Excessive Worry  Rapid Heartbeat  Sweating
cure: Practice deep breathing, engage in relaxation exercises, and consider therapy or medications if severe.
Take prescribed antipsychotic medications, undergo therapy, and maintain a strong support system.
Establish a bedtime routine, avoid caffeine before sleep, and take melatonin or sleep aids if needed.

disease: Skin Allergies  Itchy Rash  Swelling  Redness
cure: Apply antihistamine creams, take allergy medications, and avoid triggers.
Use hypoallergenic moisturizers, avoid irritants, and apply prescription topical steroids if necessary.

disease: Psoriasis  Scaly Patches  Itchy Skin  Redness
cure: Use medicated creams, light therapy, and take prescribed immune-modulating drugs.
Use benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid treatments, maintain skin hygiene, and avoid oily cosmetics.

disease: UTI  Painful Urination  Frequent Urge to Urinate  Lower Abdominal Pain
cure: Drink plenty of water, take prescribed antibiotics, and maintain good hygiene.

disease: Kidney Stones  Severe Pain in Side  Blood in Urine  Vomiting
cure: Drink lots of water, take pain relievers, and undergo lithotripsy or surgery if necessary.
Rest, drink fluids, use over-the-counter decongestants, take pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and use throat lozenges. If symptoms persist, consult a doctor.
Rest, drink plenty of fluids, take antiviral medications (e.g., oseltamivir) within 48 hours of onset, and use over-the-counter fever reducers.
Stay hydrated with water, clear soups, or oral rehydration solutions. Avoid solid food until symptoms subside. Medications like anti-nausea drugs may help, but see a doctor if dehydration occurs.
Use antihistamines (e.g., loratadine, cetirizine), nasal corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone), avoid allergens, and consider allergy shots for long-term relief.
Use bronchodilators (e.g., albuterol) as prescribed, inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone), avoid triggers, and engage in regular exercise to improve lung function.
Insulin therapy is essential, monitor blood sugar regularly, follow a healthy diet, and engage in physical activity to maintain blood sugar levels.
Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise), oral medications like metformin, and possibly insulin therapy. Regular blood sugar monitoring is crucial.
Monitor blood pressure regularly, take prescribed antihypertensive medications (e.g., ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers), and adopt a healthy diet low in salt and rich in fruits and vegetables.
Immediate emergency care, medications like aspirin and blood thinners, possibly surgery like angioplasty or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) depending on the severity.
Immediate medical attention, clot-busting medications (e.g., tPA), surgery for hemorrhagic strokes, and rehabilitation therapies to regain lost skills.
Symptomatic treatment (calamine lotion, acetaminophen), antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir) for severe cases, avoid scratching to prevent scarring.
Supportive care with fever reducers, vitamin A supplements, and keeping hydrated. Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
Long-term antibiotic therapy (e.g., rifampin, isoniazid), treatment duration usually 6-9 months, and close monitoring by healthcare providers.
Symptomatic treatment with cough suppressants, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers. Antibiotics may be prescribed if bacterial infection is suspected.
Antibiotics (for bacterial cases), antivirals (for viral causes), oxygen therapy if needed, rest, and plenty of fluids.

disease: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)chronic coughshortness of breathwheezing
cure: Bronchodilators, corticosteroids, oxygen therapy, smoking cessation, pulmonary rehabilitation programs, and avoiding irritants.
Nasal decongestants, saline nasal sprays, and antibiotics if the infection is bacterial. Surgery may be needed for chronic cases.
Antacids, proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole), H2 blockers, and lifestyle changes such as avoiding large meals and not lying down after eating.
Anti-inflammatory medications (e.g., mesalamine), immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine), and in severe cases, surgery (colectomy).
Anti-inflammatory medications (e.g., corticosteroids), immunosuppressants, antibiotics, and sometimes surgery if complications occur.
Surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy), medications to dissolve stones, and dietary changes.
Immediate surgery to remove the appendix (appendectomy) is the standard treatment.
Rest, hydration, and a healthy diet. Hepatitis A usually resolves on its own, but avoid alcohol and consult a doctor.
Antiviral medications, regular monitoring of liver function, and vaccination for prevention in at-risk individuals.
Direct-acting antivirals (e.g., sofosbuvir, ledipasvir), and regular liver function monitoring.

disease: Kidney Stonessevere pain in the backblood in urinenausea
cure: Pain relievers, increased water intake, and sometimes surgery (lithotripsy) or procedures to remove stones.

disease: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)frequent urinationburning sensationblood in urine
cure: Antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), hydration, and urinating after intercourse.
Antibiotics (e.g., nitrofurantoin), hydration, and avoiding irritants like caffeine and alcohol.
Antibiotics for bacterial infection, pain relievers, and sometimes alpha-blockers to relieve urinary symptoms.
Blood pressure control, diet modification (low sodium, low potassium), dialysis, or kidney transplant in severe cases.
Iron supplements, vitamin B12 injections, folic acid supplementation, and dietary changes.
Thyroid hormone replacement therapy for hypothyroidism, antithyroid medications for hyperthyroidism, and sometimes surgery.
Antithyroid medications (e.g., methimazole), radioactive iodine therapy, or thyroidectomy.
Thyroid hormone replacement (e.g., levothyroxine).
Pain relievers (e.g., acetaminophen, NSAIDs), physical therapy, joint injections, and sometimes joint replacement surgery.
DMARDs (e.g., methotrexate), biologics (e.g., TNF inhibitors), and corticosteroids.
Pain relievers, antidepressants (e.g., duloxetine), cognitive-behavioral therapy, and regular exercise.
Disease-modifying therapies (e.g., interferon beta), corticosteroids for flare-ups, and physical therapy.
Dopamine replacement therapy (e.g., levodopa), physical therapy, and deep brain stimulation.
Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil), NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., memantine), and supportive care.
Antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs), psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy), and lifestyle changes.
Anxiolytics (e.g., diazepam), therapy (e.g., CBT), relaxation techniques, and lifestyle changes.
Antipsychotic medications (e.g., olanzapine), therapy, and social support.

disease: Bipolar Disordermood swingsextreme highs and lows
cure: Mood stabilizers (e.g., lithium), antipsychotics, psychotherapy, and lifestyle modifications.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), and sometimes exposure therapy.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), medication (SSRIs), exposure therapy, and support groups.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), sleep hygiene, medication (e.g., melatonin or benzodiazepines) for short-term use.

disease: Restless Leg Syndromeurge to move legsdiscomfort at night
cure: Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole), iron supplements, and lifestyle changes.
Topical treatments (e.g., steroids, vitamin D analogs), phototherapy, and systemic medications (e.g., methotrexate).
Topical treatments (benzoyl peroxide, retinoids), oral antibiotics, and hormonal therapy.

Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin), wound care, and rest.

Antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir), pain relievers, and sometimes corticosteroids.
Antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline) if caught early, and symptom management.
Antimalarial medications (e.g., chloroquine, artemisinin-based treatments).
Antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone), and hydration.
Antibiotics, cough medications, and supportive care.
Supportive care (hydration, pain relievers), and rest.
Symptomatic treatment (hydration, fever relievers), avoid mosquito bites.
Rest, hydration, antiviral medications (e.g., remdesivir), oxygen therapy for severe cases.
Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin), pain relievers, and rest.
Antibiotics (for bacterial cases), antihistamines (for allergic cases), and warm compresses.
Rest, avoid strenuous activity, and monitor for worsening symptoms. Seek medical attention if symptoms persist.
Immobilization (cast or splint), pain management, surgery for complex fractures.
Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (R.I.C.E.), pain relievers.
Rest, ice, anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy.
Wrist splints, physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, and sometimes surgery.

disease: HIV/AIDS  weak immune system  recurrent infections
cure: Antiretroviral therapy (ART), regular monitoring, healthy diet, and infection prevention.

disease: Tuberculosis  chronic cough  night sweats  weight loss
cure: Long-term antibiotics (Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol), proper ventilation.
Antimalarial drugs (Chloroquine, Artemisinin-based therapies), mosquito prevention.

disease: Hepatitis B  jaundice  liver pain  fatigue
cure: Antiviral medications (Tenofovir, Entecavir), liver monitoring, vaccination for prevention.

disease: Influenza  body aches  sore throat  fever
cure: Antivirals (Oseltamivir, Zanamivir), rest, hydration, flu vaccine for prevention.

disease: Dengue Fever  severe headache  joint pain  rash
cure: Supportive care, fluids, acetaminophen (avoid NSAIDs), mosquito prevention.
Supportive care (IV fluids, electrolytes), monoclonal antibodies (Inmazeb), strict isolation.

disease: Zika Virus  rash  fever  joint pain  red eyes
cure: Symptomatic relief (rest, hydration, pain relievers), mosquito control.
Oral rehydration therapy (ORT), IV fluids, antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin).

disease: Typhoid Fever  high fever  abdominal pain  weakness
cure: Antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin, Azithromycin), hydration, proper sanitation.

disease: Plague  swollen lymph nodes  fever  chills
cure: Antibiotics (Streptomycin, Doxycycline), early detection, flea control.
Antibiotics (Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin), corticosteroids, vaccination.

disease: Sepsis  high heart rate  confusion  fever
cure: IV antibiotics, fluids, oxygen therapy, hospitalization.

disease: Lyme Disease  bullseye rash  joint pain  fatigue

Rabies vaccine, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), immediate wound care.
Supportive care, Vitamin A, MMR vaccine for prevention.
Tetanus immunoglobulin, antibiotics (Metronidazole), muscle relaxants.

Antibiotics (Azithromycin, Clarithromycin), vaccination (DTaP).

disease: Cardiovascular Disease  chest pain  shortness of breath
cure: Lifestyle changes, statins, beta-blockers, aspirin, surgery if needed.
Insulin therapy (Type 1), oral medications (Metformin), lifestyle modifications.

disease: COPD  chronic cough  shortness of breath
cure: Bronchodilators, steroids, oxygen therapy, smoking cessation.
Inhalers (Albuterol, Steroids), avoid triggers, allergy management.
Medications (Donepezil, Memantine), cognitive therapy, caregiver support.

disease: Obesity  weight gain  difficulty in movement
cure: Lifestyle changes, diet modifications, exercise, weight-loss surgery.
